case_vignette: A 65-year-old man is brought to the    emergency department after coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum at his nursing home. He recently had an upper    respirat   ory tract infection that was treated  with antibiotics.    He has a long-standing history of produc tive cough that has worsened since he had a stroke 3 years ago. He smoked a pack of cigar   ettes daily for 40 years until the stroke, aft er which he quit. The patient appears distressed and short of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F),    puls  e is 92/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm H   g. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxyg  en saturation of 92%. Physical examination shows digi   tal clubb  ing and cyanosis of the lips. Coarse crackles are heard i   n  the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field.
question: Wh ich  is the most    likely diagnos  is?
